This is a great product if you are looking for something that gives you "slip" - which I've found to be really great if your hair is really tangled and damaged - after washing hair, just glop this on the damaged section and it makes that section easier to comb through...or massage it into hair and sit under dryer.

I then wash my hair once a week with my Mizani shampoo (shampoo 3 times) and deep condition it with the silk cream conditioner (cover with plastic cap and sit under hooded dryer for 15 minutes)between reconstructing treatments.
I apply the product to my freshly washed hair, apply a shower cap, cover with a warm towel, and let set for as long as desired.

passages.text: I really like the use of both the shampoos.
Most people use shampoo...
So this is my regime - 5 Days a Week Revita Shampoo & Conditioner and 2 days I use Regenepure Shampoo and Conditioner.
For people use to normal shampoo, it might seem that your hair is not that clean and you will use more than the normal amount.
And for myself Nioxon shampoo once a week to for a cleaner feeling shampoo.
Using both, not at the same time, but different days has left my hair with the same great results as before, but feeling more full and moisturized.
I'll probably purchase one more set, then go back to using a regular shampoo and conditioner.
But, I have four bottles (two shampoo and two conditioner), and I will use them until I find something better.
And note that you do not need to wash your hair every day and sometime a good rinse would do if it is not dirty.

comments: I really like the use of both the shampoos.

For people use to normal shampoo, it might seem that your hair is not that clean and you will use more than the normal amount.
Using both, not at the same time, but different days has left my hair with the same great results as before, but feeling more full and moisturized.
I'll probably purchase one more set, then go back to using a regular shampoo and conditioner.
But, I have four bottles (two shampoo and two conditioner), and I will use them until I find something better.
So this is my regime - 5 Days a Week Revita Shampoo & Conditioner and 2 days I use Regenepure Shampoo and Conditioner.
And for myself Nioxon shampoo once a week to for a cleaner feeling shampoo.
And note that you do not need to wash your hair every day and sometime a good rinse would do if it is not dirty.

 Question: """Please don't shoot me, how does this compare with 24-70 2.8 as a general walk around lense. I am investing in a 750, don't know which lens to buy?"""
JSON List: """[{'comments': ['I like the 24-70 better but this lens is a good all around optic for everyday shooting.', 'But as you can see, 24 70 is heavier and more expensive even though it has smaller zoom ratio.', 'In short this lens makes d800 as a practical usable camera for handheld shots due to VR II.So my 24-70 is no longer of good use.. even though it is better build I think, but with 36.3 MP on d800 you need to have precise hand technique or tripod or VR.', "It's not that the 24-120mm is bad, it's more that the 80-200mm is THAT GOOD!", "I'm sure the 24-70mm owners will disagree with this, but that is my finding.", "Though a slight step down from the best lenses, construction quality seems very good, and the lens seems to handle effortlessly on my bulky D3 as well as on my smaller D300.Make no mistake, I'd never give up my 24-70 for one of the new 24-120 lenses.", 'This is one lens which could replace 24-70 / 2.8,  70-200 2.8 VR II (up to some extent) for "everyday" use.', 'I briefly considered the 24-70, but the extra reach, vibration reduction, and lower price point sold me on this lens.  ', 'Otherwise this lens is best you have got for handheld shots for this focal range of 24-120.Another great thing about this lens is VR II which is handy when I am asking my family member to use the camera, which eliminates the handshake.', "VRII.Originally the 24-70 f/2.8 was on my hotlist, but  first off, I'm big on image stabilization for hand-held shots at very low shutter speeds, a feature the 24-70 lacks.", 'As has been said many times before: "the best lens is the one you will use", and I know I wouldn\'t use the 24-70mm F2.8 because it\'s too heavy and bulky to take on backpacking/camping trips and when traveling abroad.', "At less than half the price of the 24-120 it's definitely an attractive alternative, but you do sacrifice quite a bit of performance by going with a consumer-grade lens.  ", "I'd go out with the 24-120 on my D3 and get some shots that would have been keepers with (say) the 24-70, but ended up disappointing with the 24-120.", "I bought this lens the day it came out and having used 24-70 f2.8 and 70-200 f2.8 II for about a year before, I honestly didn't expect much from this lens.", "Optically it's much better than the 24-85 and very close to the 24-70.", 'Would the 24-70mm f2.8 be any better at 50mm?', "In addition to that extra stop (f/2.8 vs. f/4), the 24-70 is one of the world's best in its range...", "besides, i don't think I've ever shot the 24-70 wider than 5.6 anyway.", 'Now the 24-70 f/2.8.  ', 'It is extremely sharp (even wide open) with excellent contrast and has a very useful zoom range to boot!I debated between the 24-70mm and this lens.', 'The biggest pro for the 24-70mm is the extra 1 stop of light, slightly quicker autofocus speed, and of course the corresponding softer bokeh due to the 1 stop aperture opening.', 'The 24-120 is free of that distortiin and is an incredible lens.', "The problem is, I'm comparing the output with my 24-70 f/2.8, 70-200 vrII f/2.8, and 200mm f/2.", 'Even though it has a f/3.5-4.5 variable aperture which doesn\'t exactly scream "professional" it\'s still a decent full frame lens which should be considered when choosing a walk-around zoom lens.  ', "Sure, it's not perfect, but neither is the 24-70mm F2.8.", 'However I DO hope that I have bought that 24 70 instead, given that I am to possess one zoom lens anyway.', "This lens has a more flexible focal range as well, and is lighter and smallerI've tested it on a D700 and its a good lens and acceptably sharp!It is a sharp lens that is very comparable to professional lenses such as Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G and Nikon 70-200mm f/2.8G VR IIVibration Reduction is extremely useful!!!Thank you Nikon!!!", 'Hence, it has my recommendation!EDIT: I write this only to confirm a statement I made in the text, about this lens being lighter than the AF-S 24-70.  ', "comparable)@120mm - Interestingly, at this focal length the differences between the 24-120mm F4 and the 80-200mm F2.8 aren't as obvious as they were at 85mm.", "But I'd really like to see a 24-100+ lens that's at least F2.8 at 24mm and with less distortion issues and absolutely no vignetting.", "I wouldn't be at all surprised if the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8 is vastly superior to the 24-120mm at 35mm.", "The 24-120 has good reach, good image quality, not heavy, not that expensive for what it can do (constant f/4 in a zoom is very respectable) and it's also the only usable medium-telephoto FX zoom from Nikon with the VR technology.", "Much later, in Spain, I also walked a lot with my AF-S 24-70 (which I took with because it's faster), but I was not as dilapidated whenever I came back from my excursions as I was when I walked with the 24-120.  ", 'Still, the 24-120 is finally at a stage where you can carry it around on your FX camera and have no regrets.', 'I thought about saving up for 24-70 f2.8 but the size, weight, limited range and lack of VR on that lens put me off.', 'The 24-120 is "good enough", but you marvel more at the way Nikon made all the design trade-offs, rather than feeling that you have a lens that\'s about no-compromise absolute top image quality.', 'My backup for that ha been my 28-70/f2.8.Now, my primary working mid-range zoom is this one, and my 24-70/f2.8 is my backup.  ', 'I\'m lucky enough to own the "magic quartet" of Nikon zooms (14-24, 24-70, 70-200, 200-400) but I get lazy like everyone else and would like to have a single walk-around lens.', "Here's why:The only other versatile walk-around FX lenses offered by Nikon are the 28-300 and the 24-70.  ", 'If you can afford it, spend the couple hundred extra and buy the 24-70 if you need to shoot wide.', 'There is lens distortion at the short focal lengths that I only notice when shooting street scenes with the 800E.  No worse than the 16-85mm on the D300.  ', 'In a nutshell, this is a very different lens than either of the earlier 24-120 products.', 'Except maybe in very low light, I actually got better results with the D300 and the 16-85, versus the D3 and 24-120.', 'All in all, the 24-120 f4 is an excellent piece of glass and vastly superior to the 18-200.That same famous reviewer who gave me the bad advice about the 18-200 says that people should ignore the new 24-120 f4 in favour of the new Nikon 28-300.', "From everything I've read, and image samples I've seen, there's no reason to believe that the Nikkor 24-70mm is any different from the rest of the 24-70mm F2.8 lenses on the market today: inconsistent performance and massive bulk and weight.", 'But my copy of this lens turned out to be just as sharp as the highly regarded 24-70, only lighter, smaller, and with VR.', 'However I did notice the 24-120 has good contrast - certainly better than the Nikon 24-85.After a lot of pixel peeping I took the lens out for some proper photography.  ', "Though at the same time if my lens kit was missing some other important lenses then I'd probably go with the 24-85 VR and use the savings toward something else.  ", 'The sales rep recommended the Nikkor 24-120mm f/4 suggesting I would get decent results without spending a lot of money (as in the 28-70mm f/2.8 lens that I was eyeing).I took advantage of the Nikon rebate event earlier this year and purchased the Nikkor 24-120mm f/4 lens.  ', 'My old, made for film, 24-120 "D" lens is much better then either.  ', "It's lighter than the AFS 24-70 (but slower), and a bit heavier than its predecessor, the AF-S VRI 24-120 of variable aperture, and also heavier than it's cousin, the plasticky AF-S 24-85.  ", 'I used to have the 24-120mm f/3.5-5.6 (until it took a dip into the ocean) and this one is a step up.', "I've owned a Canon 28-70mm f2.8L, a way overrated lens with inconsistent performance across its focal range, with massive bulk and weight.", 'On my DX camera, I came to like the 16-85 - the same 5x zoom range as the 24-120, but with much better image quality.', 'So, if you want a 4+ star walk-around lens that covers a great range, this is the best on the market.', "But keep in mind that we're comparing it to the Nikkor 80-200mm F2.8D ED lens; a VERY SHARP lens that has near perfect flat field performance with absolutely no distortion.", 'If you want the best with D800 then you must use prime 28/50(1.8)/85(1.4) with TRIPOD.', 'Also, I have 35 1.8 & a 50 1.4 for low light situations.', 'If money is not a real issue then 24-120 f/4 should still be your first choice.', 'There are absolute uses for VR beyond shaky hands!When taking landscape pictures, I stop the lens down to 8-11 and I cannot tell the difference between this and the 24-70mm.', 'The micro contrast difference between the two lenses is readily noticeable, with the 80-200mm spanking the 24-120mm.', 'I think the optics are probably almost the same but the 28-300 has a variable f-stop 3.5 - 5.6.', 'That, and the fact that this lens is a half pound lighter than the 24-70mm F/2.8 make it my go-to lens which hardly ever leaves the camera body.', 'My conclusions are that the 24-120mm F4 is an EXCELLENT lens that holds up very well with the other lenses in my kit.', 'I consider it a low five, high four... depending on your camera, your other lenses, and the size of your wallet.', "I wouldn't trade it for the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8 even if it were an even trade with no extra money out of my pocket.", 'All of my testing leads me to believe that the 24-120mm F4 can indeed compete head-to-head with the 24-70mm f2.8.=========================================Results of my tests(all done with a D600)=========================================@24mm -', 'Combined with the fact that it collects more light (f4 vs f5.6), the fact that it has Vibration Reduction II, and the fact that it zooms to 120mm, this lens offers a lot of features as a "go to" general purpose lens for FX shooters (and DX shooters as well).For DX shooters, the 24mm wide-end will not always be wide enough.', 'I tried the old 24-120 VR lens after the f/4 version, and it was about as good as the f/4 version at less then half the price.  ', 'people like to compare this with the cheaper 28-300 lens.', 'I also own 16-85mm but 24-120mm definitely has better contrast and color.', "How is this not the best value for the money in the walk-around zoom lens segment?***************UPDATE***************************A new 24-85mm with VR has been added to Nikon's line up.  ", 'In the center of the frame it is almost identical to my 24-70 2.8.', "I have an upcoming stay in Spain, and I'm seriously considering taking this lens instead of my AF-S 24-70 because of its size and zoom range.  ", "If you don't have a wide angle lens then I would probably recommend the 16-85 instead.", "I've owned a Nikon 24-70 for quite a while and it's an amazing lens.", 'The biggest issue with this zoom (and the 24-70mm) is the high distortion.', 'I looked at the 24-70 2.8 but way too expensive and heavy.', "Speaking as  Nikon shooter since the mid-1970's, I have never been so pleasantly surprised as I was over the performance of this 24-120/f4, and I own and have owed over 50 of the higher end Nikon lenses.", 'I think image quality is pretty comparable to 24-70.  ', 'When compared against my Nikkor 50mm F1.4D the 24-120mm is actually sharper at the edges at f8 and f11!', 'Still, the difference in image quality was just too noticeable when I wimped out and took the 24-120 instead of the "real lenses".', "At this focal length, the 24-120mm F4 is EXCELLENT!@35mm - I don't own a 35mm prime, but when compared to the 16-35mm F4 there truly is no comparison.", 'Not as "creamy" as that of my 80-200mm F2.8(obviously), but very useful if you know how to choose your backgrounds.', 'I also have similar Canon "L" lens 24-105 mm for roughly the same price and it is much better built.', 'On a D700, impressively sharp and reasonably contrasty at 24mm but with lots of barrel distortion.  ', 'Must be seen to be appreciated.(on a side note: I did a test with a borrowed Nikkor 85mm F1.8G -vs- my Nikkor 80-200mm', 'Unless you are looking under the microscope the image quality is not that different from the 24-120 and can be matched with some slight adjustments in post-processing (add contrast, add saturation, add sharpening).  ', 'This lens consistently delivers sharp photos compared to 24-70 /2.8 nikkor for "handheld" style.', 'Like other reviewers I had the previous version of the 24-120 and it performed poorly on my D700.  ', 'If you shoot with a DX format camera this lens will be an effective 36mm - 180mm f-4, so I can use it on both my D7100 and D300s.', "It's kind of heavy but no where near 24-70mm.", 'Great flexibility of use from portraits, still life, landscapes and streetscapes to almost macro work.  Works great as a short telephoto on my Nikon D300, too, with an equivalent of 36-180mm.  ', "I don't see a practical, real world, application where the prime would be more useful than the 24-120mm F4 for low light work; specially given that the zoom has VR.", "Also, I've never been a huge proponent of VR lenses, but the VR in the 24-120/f4 works so well that it's actually very useful, unlike other VR lenses that I own or have owned.", 'This is a good thing, since it is a well-known fact, according to most every lens test on the net, that the 16-35mm F4 is sharper across the frame at 24mm than the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8; the latter suffering from horrendous border softness at 24mm.', "Losing a stop to the 24-70 isn't a big deal - just crank up the ISO a stop.", "Yes, you have to use a tripod with that lens if you are going to shoot at 70mm and 1/45th, which I'm often required to do.", "For landscapes, it's not really any better than the 18-200 VR, unless you have a specific focal element, then it shines.", 'I have this lens paired with a 12-24 wide angle so it works better for me than the 16-85.  ', 'http://www.photozone.de/nikon_ff/574-nikkorafs24120f4vrff?start=1@70mm - I have no other lens to compare it against, but it seems equally sharp at 70mm and 50mm.', 'The first and last cons is what pushes over to the 24-120mm side, but the extra focal range and $500 less is nothing to sneeze at.', "I've performed a number of tests with the 24-120mm F4 -vs- the other lenses in my kit.", 'When compared to my Nikkor 80-200mm the 24-120mm F4 shows considerably less resolution in the middle all the way to the edges of the frame.', 'Only reason why I use it for work and not the 24-120 f/4 is the extra f/stop.  ', 'My lens kit includes the following: Nikkor 16-35mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 24-120mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 80-200mm F2.8D ED, Nikkor 50mm f1.4D. I\'ve owned the 24-120mm F4 for the past six months and before that I used my 50mm 1.4D prime as my main "mid-range" lens.', 'I shoot with a Nikon D700 and a Nikon F100 film camera and typically use prime lenses (20, 35, 85, 105), but found myself in several situations where I wanted the versatility of a zoom.', 'I compared to my Nikon 70-300mm and the 70-300 was clearly sharper at the edges at all focal lengths and apertures.  ', 'There were other little dissapontments for me with this lens so I decided to return it and get a used Nikon 24-80 2.8f instead which, I like very much a lot.', "It's really heavy, 50% more expensive than the 24-120, has 50% less reach and it lacks VR.  ", 'Which means that the lens is very sharp at 70mm.@85mm - Here is where my lens sample falls down.', 'I think this lens would be a better deal if they shaved 300 off bottom line or added 600 and made it 2.8', "Now, I know the comparison to the 200mm f/2 is not fair, but I thought it would come close to the other two...it doesn't.  ", 'I am not even going to discuss the 28-300, because I care about the image quality and the constant aperture.  ', 'Besides, the zoom rings are in the "wrong" position (the zoom ring is closer to the camera in the 24-70, while this one has it farther from the body) and this can make for some awkwardness while getting used to the lens (like trying to zoom with the focusing ring, for instance).  ', 'I purchased this lens in conjunction with an overall upgrade from my Tamron lens set and this has become my go-to lens, in conjunction with the 28-200mm f2.8 (with 2x converter) and the 18-300mm for deep backpacking.  ', 'My primary "working" mid-range zoom has been the Nikon 24-70/f2.8 since it first became available.'], 'cluster_size': 117}, {'comments': ['It has the reach to be a good general purpose walk around lens.', 'I no longer had to move/walk closer (as with my 24-85mm kit lens) to my subjects.  ', "This is probably not the best lens to use for portraits because it's just not fast enough (f-stop), but for travel, chasing you kids around, or any other every day shooting this lens is perfect.", "I'm happy to report that this and the 50mm 1.8G (for in-doors and portraiture, soon to be replaced by the 85mm 1.8G) are the only two lens I bring with me on vacation.", 'The lens feels solid as a brick and has balanced weight, a high dollar lens should be heavy, want a light weight lens buy something under $500.', 'However, my experience has been odd: while in Chile, I took long walks with my D700 and this lens and I returned exhausted to my place because of what I thought was the heft of this lens (combined with the camera and battery pack).  '], 'cluster_size': 6}]"""Summary: [/INST] While answering about comparing the Nikon 24-70 2.8 and the Nikon 24-120 f/4 as general walk-around lenses:

+ 111 of comments believe that the Nikon 24-120 f/4 has a good reach for everyday shooting and eliminates the need to move closer to subjects
+ 117 of comments believe that the Nikon 24-120 f/4 is a good all-around optic for everyday shooting, offering a practical usage with the D800 due to VR II
+ 6 of comments believe that the Nikon 24-120 f/4 is a solidly built lens with balanced weight, making it a high-dollar lens should be heavy
+ 117 of comments believe that the Nikon 24-120 f/4 is a versatile lens that works great for travel, chasing kids around, or any other everyday shooting
+ 6 of comments believe that the Nikon 24-120 f/4 is a good lens for handheld shots for the focal range of 24-1

passages.text: I like the 24-70 better but this lens is a good all around optic for everyday shooting.
But as you can see, 24 70 is heavier and more expensive even though it has smaller zoom ratio.

In short this lens makes d800 as a practical usable camera for handheld shots due to VR II.So my 24-70 is no longer of good use.. even though it is better build I think, but with 36.3 MP on d800 you need to have precise hand technique or tripod or VR.
It's not that the 24-120mm is bad, it's more that the 80-200mm is THAT GOOD!
I'm sure the 24-70mm owners will disagree with this, but that is my finding.

Though a slight step down from the best lenses, construction quality seems very good, and the lens seems to handle effortlessly on my bulky D3 as well as on my smaller D300.Make no mistake, I'd never give up my 24-70 for one of the new 24-120 lenses.
This is one lens which could replace 24-70 / 2.8,  70-200 2.8 VR II (up to some extent) for "everyday" use.
I briefly considered the 24-70, but the extra reach, vibration reduction, and lower price point sold me on this lens.

Otherwise this lens is best you have got for handheld shots for this focal range of 24-120.Another great thing about this lens is VR II which is handy when I am asking my family member to use the camera, which eliminates the handshake.
VRII.Originally the 24-70 f/2.8 was on my hotlist, but  first off, I'm big on image stabilization for hand-held shots at very low shutter speeds, a feature the 24-70 lacks.

As has been said many times before: "the best lens is the one you will use", and I know I wouldn't use the 24-70mm F2.8 because it's too heavy and bulky to take on backpacking/camping trips and when traveling abroad.
At less than half the price of the 24-120 it's definitely an attractive alternative, but you do sacrifice quite a bit of performance by going with a consumer-grade lens.
I'd go out with the 24-120 on my D3 and get some shots that would have been keepers with (say) the 24-70, but ended up disappointing with the 24-120.
I bought this lens the day it came out and having used 24-70 f2.8 and 70-200 f2.8 II for about a year before, I honestly didn't expect much from this lens.
Optically it's much better than the 24-85 and very close to the 24-70.
Would the 24-70mm f2.8 be any better at 50mm?
In addition to that extra stop (f/2.8 vs. f/4), the 24-70 is one of the world's best in its range...
besides, i don't think I've ever shot the 24-70 wider than 5.6 anyway.
Now the 24-70 f/2.8.
It is extremely sharp (even wide open) with excellent contrast and has a very useful zoom range to boot!I debated between the 24-70mm and this lens.
The biggest pro for the 24-70mm is the extra 1 stop of light, slightly quicker autofocus speed, and of course the corresponding softer bokeh due to the 1 stop aperture opening.
The 24-120 is free of that distortiin and is an incredible lens.
The problem is, I'm comparing the output with my 24-70 f/2.8, 70-200 vrII f/2.8, and 200mm f/2.
Even though it has a f/3.5-4.5 variable aperture which doesn't exactly scream "professional" it's still a decent full frame lens which should be considered when choosing a walk-around zoom lens.
Sure, it's not perfect, but neither is the 24-70mm F2.8.
However I DO hope that I have bought that 24 70 instead, given that I am to possess one zoom lens anyway.

This lens has a more flexible focal range as well, and is lighter and smallerI've tested it on a D700 and its a good lens and acceptably sharp!It is a sharp lens that is very comparable to professional lenses such as Nikon 24-70mm f/2.8G and Nikon 70-200mm f/2.8G VR IIVibration Reduction is extremely useful!!!Thank you Nikon!!!
Hence, it has my recommendation!EDIT: I write this only to confirm a statement I made in the text, about this lens being lighter than the AF-S 24-70.
comparable)@120mm - Interestingly, at this focal length the differences between the 24-120mm F4 and the 80-200mm F2.8 aren't as obvious as they were at 85mm.
But I'd really like to see a 24-100+ lens that's at least F2.8 at 24mm and with less distortion issues and absolutely no vignetting.
I wouldn't be at all surprised if the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8 is vastly superior to the 24-120mm at 35mm.

The 24-120 has good reach, good image quality, not heavy, not that expensive for what it can do (constant f/4 in a zoom is very respectable) and it's also the only usable medium-telephoto FX zoom from Nikon with the VR technology.

Much later, in Spain, I also walked a lot with my AF-S 24-70 (which I took with because it's faster), but I was not as dilapidated whenever I came back from my excursions as I was when I walked with the 24-120.
Still, the 24-120 is finally at a stage where you can carry it around on your FX camera and have no regrets.
I thought about saving up for 24-70 f2.8 but the size, weight, limited range and lack of VR on that lens put me off.
The 24-120 is "good enough", but you marvel more at the way Nikon made all the design trade-offs, rather than feeling that you have a lens that's about no-compromise absolute top image quality.
My backup for that ha been my 28-70/f2.8.Now, my primary working mid-range zoom is this one, and my 24-70/f2.8 is my backup.
I'm lucky enough to own the "magic quartet" of Nikon zooms (14-24, 24-70, 70-200, 200-400) but I get lazy like everyone else and would like to have a single walk-around lens.
Here's why:The only other versatile walk-around FX lenses offered by Nikon are the 28-300 and the 24-70.
If you can afford it, spend the couple hundred extra and buy the 24-70 if you need to shoot wide.
There is lens distortion at the short focal lengths that I only notice when shooting street scenes with the 800E.  No worse than the 16-85mm on the D300.
In a nutshell, this is a very different lens than either of the earlier 24-120 products.
Except maybe in very low light, I actually got better results with the D300 and the 16-85, versus the D3 and 24-120.

All in all, the 24-120 f4 is an excellent piece of glass and vastly superior to the 18-200.That same famous reviewer who gave me the bad advice about the 18-200 says that people should ignore the new 24-120 f4 in favour of the new Nikon 28-300.

From everything I've read, and image samples I've seen, there's no reason to believe that the Nikkor 24-70mm is any different from the rest of the 24-70mm F2.8 lenses on the market today: inconsistent performance and massive bulk and weight.
But my copy of this lens turned out to be just as sharp as the highly regarded 24-70, only lighter, smaller, and with VR.
However I did notice the 24-120 has good contrast - certainly better than the Nikon 24-85.After a lot of pixel peeping I took the lens out for some proper photography.
Though at the same time if my lens kit was missing some other important lenses then I'd probably go with the 24-85 VR and use the savings toward something else.

The sales rep recommended the Nikkor 24-120mm f/4 suggesting I would get decent results without spending a lot of money (as in the 28-70mm f/2.8 lens that I was eyeing).I took advantage of the Nikon rebate event earlier this year and purchased the Nikkor 24-120mm f/4 lens.
My old, made for film, 24-120 "D" lens is much better then either.
It's lighter than the AFS 24-70 (but slower), and a bit heavier than its predecessor, the AF-S VRI 24-120 of variable aperture, and also heavier than it's cousin, the plasticky AF-S 24-85.
I used to have the 24-120mm f/3.5-5.6 (until it took a dip into the ocean) and this one is a step up.
I've owned a Canon 28-70mm f2.8L, a way overrated lens with inconsistent performance across its focal range, with massive bulk and weight.
On my DX camera, I came to like the 16-85 - the same 5x zoom range as the 24-120, but with much better image quality.
So, if you want a 4+ star walk-around lens that covers a great range, this is the best on the market.
But keep in mind that we're comparing it to the Nikkor 80-200mm F2.8D ED lens; a VERY SHARP lens that has near perfect flat field performance with absolutely no distortion.
If you want the best with D800 then you must use prime 28/50(1.8)/85(1.4) with TRIPOD.
Also, I have 35 1.8 & a 50 1.4 for low light situations.
If money is not a real issue then 24-120 f/4 should still be your first choice.
There are absolute uses for VR beyond shaky hands!When taking landscape pictures, I stop the lens down to 8-11 and I cannot tell the difference between this and the 24-70mm.
The micro contrast difference between the two lenses is readily noticeable, with the 80-200mm spanking the 24-120mm.
I think the optics are probably almost the same but the 28-300 has a variable f-stop 3.5 - 5.6.
That, and the fact that this lens is a half pound lighter than the 24-70mm F/2.8 make it my go-to lens which hardly ever leaves the camera body.
My conclusions are that the 24-120mm F4 is an EXCELLENT lens that holds up very well with the other lenses in my kit.
I consider it a low five, high four... depending on your camera, your other lenses, and the size of your wallet.
I wouldn't trade it for the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8 even if it were an even trade with no extra money out of my pocket.

All of my testing leads me to believe that the 24-120mm F4 can indeed compete head-to-head with the 24-70mm f2.8.=========================================Results of my tests(all done with a D600)=========================================@24mm -

Combined with the fact that it collects more light (f4 vs f5.6), the fact that it has Vibration Reduction II, and the fact that it zooms to 120mm, this lens offers a lot of features as a "go to" general purpose lens for FX shooters (and DX shooters as well).For DX shooters, the 24mm wide-end will not always be wide enough.
I tried the old 24-120 VR lens after the f/4 version, and it was about as good as the f/4 version at less then half the price.
people like to compare this with the cheaper 28-300 lens.
I also own 16-85mm but 24-120mm definitely has better contrast and color.
How is this not the best value for the money in the walk-around zoom lens segment?***************UPDATE***************************A new 24-85mm with VR has been added to Nikon's line up.
In the center of the frame it is almost identical to my 24-70 2.8.
I have an upcoming stay in Spain, and I'm seriously considering taking this lens instead of my AF-S 24-70 because of its size and zoom range.
It has the reach to be a good general purpose walk around lens.
If you don't have a wide angle lens then I would probably recommend the 16-85 instead.
I've owned a Nikon 24-70 for quite a while and it's an amazing lens.
The biggest issue with this zoom (and the 24-70mm) is the high distortion.
I looked at the 24-70 2.8 but way too expensive and heavy.

Speaking as  Nikon shooter since the mid-1970's, I have never been so pleasantly surprised as I was over the performance of this 24-120/f4, and I own and have owed over 50 of the higher end Nikon lenses.
I no longer had to move/walk closer (as with my 24-85mm kit lens) to my subjects.
I think image quality is pretty comparable to 24-70.
When compared against my Nikkor 50mm F1.4D the 24-120mm is actually sharper at the edges at f8 and f11!
Still, the difference in image quality was just too noticeable when I wimped out and took the 24-120 instead of the "real lenses".
At this focal length, the 24-120mm F4 is EXCELLENT!@35mm - I don't own a 35mm prime, but when compared to the 16-35mm F4 there truly is no comparison.
Not as "creamy" as that of my 80-200mm F2.8(obviously), but very useful if you know how to choose your backgrounds.
I also have similar Canon "L" lens 24-105 mm for roughly the same price and it is much better built.
On a D700, impressively sharp and reasonably contrasty at 24mm but with lots of barrel distortion.
Must be seen to be appreciated.(on a side note: I did a test with a borrowed Nikkor 85mm F1.8G -vs- my Nikkor 80-200mm

Unless you are looking under the microscope the image quality is not that different from the 24-120 and can be matched with some slight adjustments in post-processing (add contrast, add saturation, add sharpening).
This lens consistently delivers sharp photos compared to 24-70 /2.8 nikkor for "handheld" style.
Like other reviewers I had the previous version of the 24-120 and it performed poorly on my D700.
If you shoot with a DX format camera this lens will be an effective 36mm - 180mm f-4, so I can use it on both my D7100 and D300s.
It's kind of heavy but no where near 24-70mm.
Great flexibility of use from portraits, still life, landscapes and streetscapes to almost macro work.  Works great as a short telephoto on my Nikon D300, too, with an equivalent of 36-180mm.
I don't see a practical, real world, application where the prime would be more useful than the 24-120mm F4 for low light work; specially given that the zoom has VR.
Also, I've never been a huge proponent of VR lenses, but the VR in the 24-120/f4 works so well that it's actually very useful, unlike other VR lenses that I own or have owned.

This is a good thing, since it is a well-known fact, according to most every lens test on the net, that the 16-35mm F4 is sharper across the frame at 24mm than the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8; the latter suffering from horrendous border softness at 24mm.
Losing a stop to the 24-70 isn't a big deal - just crank up the ISO a stop.
Yes, you have to use a tripod with that lens if you are going to shoot at 70mm and 1/45th, which I'm often required to do.
For landscapes, it's not really any better than the 18-200 VR, unless you have a specific focal element, then it shines.
I have this lens paired with a 12-24 wide angle so it works better for me than the 16-85.
http://www.photozone.de/nikon_ff/574-nikkorafs24120f4vrff?start=1@70mm - I have no other lens to compare it against, but it seems equally sharp at 70mm and 50mm.
The first and last cons is what pushes over to the 24-120mm side, but the extra focal range and $500 less is nothing to sneeze at.
I've performed a number of tests with the 24-120mm F4 -vs- the other lenses in my kit.
When compared to my Nikkor 80-200mm the 24-120mm F4 shows considerably less resolution in the middle all the way to the edges of the frame.
Only reason why I use it for work and not the 24-120 f/4 is the extra f/stop.

My lens kit includes the following: Nikkor 16-35mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 24-120mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 80-200mm F2.8D ED, Nikkor 50mm f1.4D. I've owned the 24-120mm F4 for the past six months and before that I used my 50mm 1.4D prime as my main "mid-range" lens.
I shoot with a Nikon D700 and a Nikon F100 film camera and typically use prime lenses (20, 35, 85, 105), but found myself in several situations where I wanted the versatility of a zoom.
I compared to my Nikon 70-300mm and the 70-300 was clearly sharper at the edges at all focal lengths and apertures.
There were other little dissapontments for me with this lens so I decided to return it and get a used Nikon 24-80 2.8f instead which, I like very much a lot.
It's really heavy, 50% more expensive than the 24-120, has 50% less reach and it lacks VR.
Which means that the lens is very sharp at 70mm.@85mm - Here is where my lens sample falls down.
Ok ... I bought this to replace my old 28-70 f2.8 ...
I think this lens would be a better deal if they shaved 300 off bottom line or added 600 and made it 2.8
Now, I know the comparison to the 200mm f/2 is not fair, but I thought it would come close to the other two...it doesn't.
I am not even going to discuss the 28-300, because I care about the image quality and the constant aperture.
I purchased it to replace a 24-70.

Besides, the zoom rings are in the "wrong" position (the zoom ring is closer to the camera in the 24-70, while this one has it farther from the body) and this can make for some awkwardness while getting used to the lens (like trying to zoom with the focusing ring, for instance).
This is probably not the best lens to use for portraits because it's just not fast enough (f-stop), but for travel, chasing you kids around, or any other every day shooting this lens is perfect.
I'm happy to report that this and the 50mm 1.8G (for in-doors and portraiture, soon to be replaced by the 85mm 1.8G) are the only two lens I bring with me on vacation.

I purchased this lens in conjunction with an overall upgrade from my Tamron lens set and this has become my go-to lens, in conjunction with the 28-200mm f2.8 (with 2x converter) and the 18-300mm for deep backpacking.
The lens feels solid as a brick and has balanced weight, a high dollar lens should be heavy, want a light weight lens buy something under $500.
My primary "working" mid-range zoom has been the Nikon 24-70/f2.8 since it first became available.

However, my experience has been odd: while in Chile, I took long walks with my D700 and this lens and I returned exhausted to my place because of what I thought was the heft of this lens (combined with the camera and battery pack).

Unless you are looking under the microscope the image quality is not that different from the 24-120 and can be matched with some slight adjustments in post-processing (add contrast, add saturation, add sharpening).
This lens consistently delivers sharp photos compared to 24-70 /2.8 nikkor for "handheld" style.
Like other reviewers I had the previous version of the 24-120 and it performed poorly on my D700.
If you shoot with a DX format camera this lens will be an effective 36mm - 180mm f-4, so I can use it on both my D7100 and D300s.
It's kind of heavy but no where near 24-70mm.
Great flexibility of use from portraits, still life, landscapes and streetscapes to almost macro work.  Works great as a short telephoto on my Nikon D300, too, with an equivalent of 36-180mm.
I don't see a practical, real world, application where the prime would be more useful than the 24-120mm F4 for low light work; specially given that the zoom has VR.
Also, I've never been a huge proponent of VR lenses, but the VR in the 24-120/f4 works so well that it's actually very useful, unlike other VR lenses that I own or have owned.

This is a good thing, since it is a well-known fact, according to most every lens test on the net, that the 16-35mm F4 is sharper across the frame at 24mm than the Nikkor 24-70mm F2.8; the latter suffering from horrendous border softness at 24mm.
Losing a stop to the 24-70 isn't a big deal - just crank up the ISO a stop.
Yes, you have to use a tripod with that lens if you are going to shoot at 70mm and 1/45th, which I'm often required to do.
For landscapes, it's not really any better than the 18-200 VR, unless you have a specific focal element, then it shines.
I have this lens paired with a 12-24 wide angle so it works better for me than the 16-85.
http://www.photozone.de/nikon_ff/574-nikkorafs24120f4vrff?start=1@70mm - I have no other lens to compare it against, but it seems equally sharp at 70mm and 50mm.
The first and last cons is what pushes over to the 24-120mm side, but the extra focal range and $500 less is nothing to sneeze at.
I've performed a number of tests with the 24-120mm F4 -vs- the other lenses in my kit.
When compared to my Nikkor 80-200mm the 24-120mm F4 shows considerably less resolution in the middle all the way to the edges of the frame.
Only reason why I use it for work and not the 24-120 f/4 is the extra f/stop.

My lens kit includes the following: Nikkor 16-35mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 24-120mm F4 VRII, Nikkor 80-200mm F2.8D ED, Nikkor 50mm f1.4D. I've owned the 24-120mm F4 for the past six months and before that I used my 50mm 1.4D prime as my main "mid-range" lens.
I shoot with a Nikon D700 and a Nikon F100 film camera and typically use prime lenses (20, 35, 85, 105), but found myself in several situations where I wanted the versatility of a zoom.
I compared to my Nikon 70-300mm and the 70-300 was clearly sharper at the edges at all focal lengths and apertures.
There were other little dissapontments for me with this lens so I decided to return it and get a used Nikon 24-80 2.8f instead which, I like very much a lot.
It's really heavy, 50% more expensive than the 24-120, has 50% less reach and it lacks VR.
Which means that the lens is very sharp at 70mm.@85mm - Here is where my lens sample falls down.
I think this lens would be a better deal if they shaved 300 off bottom line or added 600 and made it 2.8
Now, I know the comparison to the 200mm f/2 is not fair, but I thought it would come close to the other two...it doesn't.
I am not even going to discuss the 28-300, because I care about the image quality and the constant aperture.

Besides, the zoom rings are in the "wrong" position (the zoom ring is closer to the camera in the 24-70, while this one has it farther from the body) and this can make for some awkwardness while getting used to the lens (like trying to zoom with the focusing ring, for instance).

I purchased this lens in conjunction with an overall upgrade from my Tamron lens set and this has become my go-to lens, in conjunction with the 28-200mm f2.8 (with 2x converter) and the 18-300mm for deep backpacking.
My primary "working" mid-range zoom has been the Nikon 24-70/f2.8 since it first became available.
It has the reach to be a good general purpose walk around lens.
I no longer had to move/walk closer (as with my 24-85mm kit lens) to my subjects.
This is probably not the best lens to use for portraits because it's just not fast enough (f-stop), but for travel, chasing you kids around, or any other every day shooting this lens is perfect.
I'm happy to report that this and the 50mm 1.8G (for in-doors and portraiture, soon to be replaced by the 85mm 1.8G) are the only two lens I bring with me on vacation.
The lens feels solid as a brick and has balanced weight, a high dollar lens should be heavy, want a light weight lens buy something under $500.

However, my experience has been odd: while in Chile, I took long walks with my D700 and this lens and I returned exhausted to my place because of what I thought was the heft of this lens (combined with the camera and battery pack).

passages.text: UPDATE 11/17/2011: To satify my curiosity, after reading reviews from the "professionals" at dpreview, I went ahead and rented the 70-200 F4-L, which is known to be the "king of image quality" for L class lenses, and guess what?
All this being said, this lens offer you performance, which far exceeds the performance of any non-L lens.
I didn't consider the highly-rated L series lenses because I knew that I wouldn't regularly carry such a large and obtrusive lens.

People swear by L lenses, but if it's between this lens and say the 70-200mm IS you're talking about a minimal difference in sharpness out of the camera, and the 70-200mm IS costs more with less of a range.
I tried to change the rating of this lens from 4 stars to 5, but the Amazon software did not reflect the change, so I will say again - mounted on my new 7D this lens is very sharp.

One other thing to keep in mind is that this is not the fastest lens (f/4.5-f/5.6), if you do a lot of low light or high speed photography, you'll either be shooting at higher ISO settings or slower lens speeds than with the L series lenses.

comments: UPDATE 11/17/2011: To satify my curiosity, after reading reviews from the "professionals" at dpreview, I went ahead and rented the 70-200 F4-L, which is known to be the "king of image quality" for L class lenses, and guess what?
All this being said, this lens offer you performance, which far exceeds the performance of any non-L lens.
I didn't consider the highly-rated L series lenses because I knew that I wouldn't regularly carry such a large and obtrusive lens.

People swear by L lenses, but if it's between this lens and say the 70-200mm IS you're talking about a minimal difference in sharpness out of the camera, and the 70-200mm IS costs more with less of a range.
I tried to change the rating of this lens from 4 stars to 5, but the Amazon software did not reflect the change, so I will say again - mounted on my new 7D this lens is very sharp.

One other thing to keep in mind is that this is not the fastest lens (f/4.5-f/5.6), if you do a lot of low light or high speed photography, you'll either be shooting at higher ISO settings or slower lens speeds than with the L series lenses.

and I started my new advanture to find perfect Digital8 camcorder.

I had a friend who had a mini dv camcorder comment on their delicate nature, and her mini dv camcorder also quit working after only a few months of normal use (think about the same price range as digital 8 now--not more costly mini
I recommend this model as I bought it since my older one stop working and I still have many family Digitla-8 tapes that I would like to watch from time to time.

Consumer Reports also states that these digital 8 camcorders are amongest the best buys in digital camcorders available today.

There's probably better and more modern camcorders out there, and if I hadn't gotten a used one for a good price, I may have considered something else, but bottom line was I was getting ready to go on vacation when my old one died and needed to be able to use the same tapes.
but if you want to playback Hi8 tapes you better get another one cause this one won't play them, it only plays Digital8 tapes.

dv camcorders).The Sony digital 8 camcorders may be discontinued soon by Sony (at least that is the asumption from what I read), but I have read more positive reviews (at this price range) for the Sony digital 8 camcorders than any of the comparable mini dv camcorders IN THIS PRICE RANGE.

As the other reviewers have noted, the TRV 280 is a very good deal as a full-featured Digital8 camcorder.

For under three 'Benjamins', you get reliable digital video and audio quality with over 500 lines of resolution, and a proven medium (Digital8) whose videotapes cost half as much or less than MiniDV tapes.
Learning to use it and getting decent footage was a breeze compared to my old VHS-C camcorder.
I am actually happy with the cameras appearence and performance but I replaced another sony 8 mm camcorder with this one
The camcorder is excellent.
As it turned out, it was cheaper to purchase the new camcorder than to pay to have all tapes transferred.

It is certainly the cheapest priced digital camcorder I could find brand new, and the best built camcorder, especially when compared to the many mini dv's available (they look like they could break if you look at them the wrong way)!
I also have a sony  trv138  camcorder the only difference is that one is digital and the other is not.
I purchased the videocamera thinking I could watch my old tapes also.
IF you are looking for a camcorder that will last you for a long time I would recommend either one of these depending on the quality of recording, I would recommend the trv280.
Also Digital8/Hi8 tapes are much cheaper that miniDV ones.
This is a great replacement and I purchased it to transfer all of my existing Digital 8 tapes to disk as the format is being phased out.

EXTENSIVE research, I have found that, for the money ($259 from Amazon w/free shipping & also getting the Amazon Visa Card for an added discount), this is the best deal as far as digital camcorders go available today.

It fits my DSLR with 35mm lens and a spare 35-300mm lens.

I was able to fit all of my camera equipment in the backpack with not much room to spare (D3200 w/ 18-55mm lens, 55-200mm lens, lens hood, 2 batteries, battery charger, micro fiber cloth and spare lens cap).

The main compartment has space for the camera with zoom lens attached (i have a 55-250mm and it could fit something slightly longer) plus a sub-compartment for one standard lens - it's a snug fit for my 18-55mm, which means I have to keep the zoom lens either attached to the camera in the main compartment, or in the other top compartment where it wouldn't be as well protected, especially if I want to keep other accessories in there.
That's my only issue, but if you're just carrying around 2 lenses it's sufficient.

Check local electronic manufacturers or such for foam leftovers instead of ordering from Pelican and save $$$.After the modifications, it holds my Canon with 70/200 L series(most used) lens attached in the main(double zip)compartment on top of my 18/55MM & 2X extender lens(accessed thru the front zipper)- all well padded & secure.
I can fit all my cleaning gear, several filter backs, a large sigma 28-300 lens as well as a smaller cannon lens, as well as a 20D body.

Except for the aforementioned 7d and L lens (which by the way does fit in the bag if I remove the floor from the small top area...but nothing else would fit), and maybe some extra filters, everything fits.

It easily held the Nikon 3200, the 18-55 lens, a 55-200 lens, a couple of extra batteries, a pelican case for 6 SD cards, water bottle (side pouch), wallet, passport, pack of tissues, and still had room for a handful of granola bars and misc.
The BIIN 47 is the perfect size for a 55-300mm lens, another prime lens, and a DSLR w/ lens attached.
It has three interior dividers which can be reconfigured to fit the camera with lens attached, plus 1-2 additional lenses.

+ 11 comments think that USB 3.0 requires fast drives to achieve its speed.

+ 7 comments state that USB 3.0 speed is 5Gbps.  
+ 8 comments believe that FireWire is the slowest interface compared to USB 3.0 and Thunderbolt.

passages.text: And for those who are wondering, the new USB 3.0 is significantly faster than Firewire.
I tested it on both Firewire and USB 3 and it is very fast.
It's considerably faster with the Firewire cable.

I use the FireWire port on my Macbook Pro 2011 and it's quick; Boots OSX from an external faster than Win7 boots from the internal drive (maybe not saying MUCH...but that's something).The reason I bought this was my last enclosure, with a 12mm (tall) 1TB drive, was too crowded and got BLAZING hot; NOT this one...under heavy use the chassis barely got above room temp.

There is some forward thinking with this enclosure: It is set up for the fastest connections via USB 3.0 and FireWire 800 at a time when many laptops and desktop computers are still using the older USB 2.0 and FireWire 400 standards.
I put a 500GB @7200 rpm and ithe transfer using firewire is good 60MB W/ 70MB R.Didnt test USB 3.0 since I dont have any
It's small, rugged, and has both Firewire 800 support and high speed USB.
Since I have a pre USB 3 MacBook Pro, the Firewire 800 makes for a much better interface than the USB 2.

Though it cost a bit more than I would have liked, it at least had both Firewire 800 and USB 3.0 so I could use it with the MacBook Pro that I have now and should be good for next MacBook Pro that I will eventually buy.
I had another USB 3 external enclosure that I thought was fast, but it did not have Firewire 800.
I tested my drive speed with both the USB 3.0 connected to USB 2.0 port to my laptop and with the Firewire 800 cable.
Firewire 800, USB 3.0 and powered from the cables.

This enclosure is a bit more expensive than USB 3 only enclosures, but if you are looking for the best overall performance then this is a really good choice.btw, I also tested Thunderbolt enclosures and the USB is just as fast or faster.
It's small, classy, very well made, and fast due to the FireWire 800 port.

FW speed was Write 75.2MB/sec/ Read 77.1MB/sec on average, but testing on the USB 3 (using my friend's new Macbook Pro Retina) it was about the same, maybe a bit faster, but really not much of a difference.
It has all the connectivity I need at the moment — FireWire 800 and USB 3.0 — and is very sturdily built using thick aluminum alloy.
Comes with Firewire, USB, and Power cables.
This product works great and was easily out performing usb 2.0.  typical transfer speed was around 25MB/sec when usb 2.0 (computer ports only have 2.0) was transferring around 3-5 MB/sec.
Both FireWire and USB use the Oxford Chipsets, which is a big plus as they are the industry leaders.
I'm very grateful for the 800 and the USB 3.0 ports to allow me time to bridge the gap between my current firewire 800 machine and a future upgrade.
It is a little more expensive than most, but having both FW800 and USB 3.0 lets me get the best speed for both new and old Macs.

Both will mount, but then simple things like opening them or Get Info take a long time, and attempting any file copy will simply freeze it & require to pull the plug.- I tried 2 different USB3 cables, made sure to connect the second connector for extra power.- Both drives worked fine, no errors or slowdowns, in another enclosure, with the Macbook Air.- This enclosure, with either drive, worked fine connected to an older Macbook, both with USB2(!) and Firewire 800But this particular configuration does not work, maybe due to some incompatibility with the Oxford USB3 chipset?
It would have been great if it came with a case, rather than a power supply, (since power is easily supplied through the USB/Firewire bus).
I tested the drive with Firewire 800 and confirmed that it registers ~115MB/s.
I ordered this because I needed FireWire 800 and USB 3.0.
It is even is getting the full speed of my firewire 800 port on my macbook.
But honestly I don't care - I was looking for firewire 800 and USB3 in one enclosure and if its working fine I wouldn't mind2.USB - not working at all with macbook airs, not possible to format.
It was great on FireWire, but when I got my Retina MacbookPro this enclosure did not work well on USB 3.0, worked fine on USB 2.0 though.
The Firewire 800 provides power to the drive so you don't need to use the power supply included if your computer is plugged in.
When I first tested this enclosure with a 1TB WD Scorpio Blue drive, I was disappointed that I was only getting around 52MB/s read and write speeds over USB 3.0.
It even came with all the required and extra cables to make it work ( i.e. power if needed, firewire, and usb cable).
Speed: I've tested both for FW and USB 3.0.
I'm probably not alone in that I found the MiniPro while looking for a 2.5in enclosure with both USB 3.0 and FireWire 800 ports.

If I have to connect to my older Mac, I use this cable:LaCie FireWire 400 to FireWire 800 Flat Cable (130849)The enclosure came with a very heavy-duty black 2-ft. FireWire 800 cable that is about a quarter inch thick.
For me, it makes no sense to use the USB 3.0 port on the enclosure when I have FireWire ports, so I have stuck to FireWire.
I bought the MiniPro so I would have a fast drive that would work with USB 3 and firewire Macs.
Not sure why anything with a firewire 800 port is instantly double the price, but I suppose they realize there is still a demand and not much supply out there anymore.
I got well over 100MB/s over USB 3.0 and 80-something with FW800, both respectable numbers for a 5400rpm drive.
Can be powered by firewire, USB3 or included power adaptor.
I got it because I wanted to keep my USB ports available even while I was using the external drive (thus I planned to use the firewire ports).

Firewire - fortunately it is possible to format with firewire, but.. not possible to boot via firewire!!!I bought this one to use with SSD drive to speed-up my old iMac (booting from SSD via firewire).

so up to you, i'll try the 800 fire wire lateri did try it with with the 800Fire wire it shows (((((34.6 -38.4 mbp)))my PCI is the SIIG fIREWIRE 800 3-Port PCImy OS is win7 Ultimate x64my PC : I7, 6GB SDRAM Patriotbut as i mention before..
The silver one looks really really good, especially next to a Macbook Pro.FW800 is plenty fast, but it also has USB3.0 for use in the future.
Very hard to fine a decent Firewire 800/USB3 enclosure.
Connecting the same drive to the same system via USB3, I got read/write speeds of 55MB/s and 55MB/s.
I was looking for an external drive case for a 2.5" SATA drive that, ideally, had Thunderbolt and Firewire 800 for a reasonable price.

This device works fine on Mac with bus power over FW800 and USB 2.0.However, even using the provided power adapter on both my USB 3.0 and USB 2.0 drives the device constantly mounts and unmounts (every few seconds).
(And yet I have another drive, same exact model WD 2TB, using another Oyen Digital enclosure, but for some reason that was slower, FW speed Write 51.1MB/sec Read 51.7MB/sec.
The hard drive fits snuggly in the unit and it comes with firewire 800 and USB 3 cables.

The enclosure is attractive, but feels just a little cheap, probably because it is so light (which could be a good thing if you travel).Transfer speeds are fast, but the big determining factor was not the SSD drive, but the source hard drive (which is typically 5400 rpm for internal laptop drives).
I recommend that you save money and a Thunderbolt port and leverage the USB 3 ports on your Mac for external drives.
I get ~400MB/s read and write speeds with this enclosure, my SSD, and USB 3.
I wanted at least one enclosure that is forward compatible with USB3 and that had Firewire 800 as well and this fit the bill.
Obviously this does nothing but allow you to hook up via usb3.0 or FireWire, but not use any other port.
Firewire 800 was a must for me.
I wanted an enclosure that would work with my present firewire 800 Mac and also for the future when I got a new Mac with USB 3 ports.
I get around 75MB/sec for Read/Write under FW800 on a 5400RPM drive that I removed from my factory MBP.One thing I did dislike is the black FW800 cable that came with it.

I put a new SS drive in and clone my internal HD - took about an hour if I recall correctly using the Firewire 800; then replaced the internal HD with the SS and put my old HD as the external drive - so now I have the SS high speed drive and know that I have plenty of spare space in my old HD for backups etc.
That drive received a read/write of 102MB/s and 104MB/s via USB3.
It is able to saturate the FW800 bus on Mac (80MB/s read and write) which is 80-90% of the theoretical max, so that's good.
My older Mac laptop has FireWire 400 ports, but my company Mac has 800 ports.
I purchased this item because I needed an enclosure that supported Firewire and USB.
Love the daisy-chain ability with my other Firewire drives.
It's not Thunderbolt but far cheaper and very usable for compact backup & storage.

It's novel, but not much different form regular sugar -- especially since we use raw sugar anyway...
Though it's slightly more costly than something like agave or coconut sugar, the fact the flavor is so unobtrusive makes a big difference for me.
This, IF you stirr, is sweeter then sugar using less of it.

Having been to Teavana(the shop) and tasted their samples, in which they use this sugar as a sweetener, I know they must use tons of the stuff to get their tea sweet and I feel like it's kind of dodgy that they don't tell you how much of the sugar you'll need to use to achieve those same levels of sweetness.
I could almost detect a molasses-type flavor with the Sugar in the Raw.

I also tried my boyfriend's Sugar in the Raw (15 calories, 4g sugar carbs) and it, too, seemed to mask the flavor of teas I had originally used with the rock sugar (Anjou Pearadise, Youthberry/Wild Orange, and similar blends).
I admit, I didn't think for a second there would be a difference between this sugar and regular sugar, short of one being cooler looking than the other.
It is going to sound sacrilegious, but I mix equal amounts rock sugar with raw sugar.
It tastes good but then again, it's sugar and sugar tastes good.
The rock sugar would be more sugar per teaspoon than the raw sugar.

comments: Just think of a spoonful of rock sugar and then think a spoonful of raw sugar.
It's novel, but not much different form regular sugar -- especially since we use raw sugar anyway...
Though it's slightly more costly than something like agave or coconut sugar, the fact the flavor is so unobtrusive makes a big difference for me.
This, IF you stirr, is sweeter then sugar using less of it.

Having been to Teavana(the shop) and tasted their samples, in which they use this sugar as a sweetener, I know they must use tons of the stuff to get their tea sweet and I feel like it's kind of dodgy that they don't tell you how much of the sugar you'll need to use to achieve those same levels of sweetness.

I also tried my boyfriend's Sugar in the Raw (15 calories, 4g sugar carbs) and it, too, seemed to mask the flavor of teas I had originally used with the rock sugar (Anjou Pearadise, Youthberry/Wild Orange, and similar blends).
I admit, I didn't think for a second there would be a difference between this sugar and regular sugar, short of one being cooler looking than the other.
It is going to sound sacrilegious, but I mix equal amounts rock sugar with raw sugar.
It tastes good but then again, it's sugar and sugar tastes good.
The rock sugar would be more sugar per teaspoon than the raw sugar.

but if you do expose to over 140 then put in a freezer at 14 or lower....sure enough, I put the notebook in the freezer and in 3 hours the ink is readable again (but not as dark as before) ...
Keep in mind the heat from friction is what causes the ink to disappear so if you leave your notes out on a hot summer day, your ink might disappear.
The ink is completely erasble and doesn't smudge on your hand as you write.
It also doesn't work the other way around, meaning you can't use the pen's eraser to erase ink from a regular pen.
But, I notice that the ink uses up more than usual, so this pen will run out 2-3 times faster than a normal pen, so you should carry around the refills that comes with the pen.
More importantly, a new pen that's been sitting in a drawer or a lightly used one standing in a desk organizer idle for a few months should work instantly.

I use it so much I've already replaced one of the ink cartridges (definitely a good idea to get them with the refills).I also recommend buying a frixion eraser for the pens because the little eraser on the top does begin to wear away slowly (very very slowly).
As for the erased ink, I have no idea where it disappears to, because I don't notice much of it getting stuck on the eraser after erasing.
The pen also clicks using the transparent hook, so that you don't accidently click while erasing, but you might accidently click if you, lets say, hook it to your shirt pocket (not in issue for me).
writes well; erases without a mark (does require the hand to push harder on paper, in some cases causing the paper to be uneven)great pen!
That being said, the refills fit in either the old or the new pen, so I am thinking of just putting the new ink in the old pens, because the ink/eraser is what they're all about anyways.
Unlike other pens where you MIGHT be able to erase some things if you REALLY want to, these can be used just like a pencil with a good eraser.

passages.text: Unfortunately, my MP280 Canon printer indicates that there's no level of ink detected.
Unfortunately, the printer failed to recognize the new cartridge due to it being refilled and not brand-new.
as soon as i installed cartridge, my printer gave me the ink running low signal.
loaded the replacement cartridge  -- my canon printer read "no ink"  -- tried several times to get it "flowing"  -- I think the printer was right -- no ink.
Ink level indicator window may prompt cartridge as empty or low.
My printer did not recognize this cartridge and would not continue printing until I replaced it with a didn't cartridge, even though it was brand new.
I put I  in my printer an  printed a few thing  and the ink is already low.
Printer doesn't acknowledge that it has ink, but it does print fine.

While I appreciated their suggestions on how to make the printer accept the new ink cartridge, it was difficult to get them to understand that the printer was COMPUTERIZED, and therefore I couldn't simply "ignore" the failure to recognize the cartridge.

But the printer wont print at all, there is no way to "ignore the message", because it says the cartridge is empty and it should be replaced...and that is the only thing you must do if you want the printer to print.
I'm sure that by acknowledging you're using refurbished ink you void some sort of warranty, but honestly, if you buy Canon ink 2-3 times you've already paid the cost of a new printer.
My printer recognized it just fine, I've had no issues and I will buy it again when my ink runs out.
Prints out with quality, although the printer says ink is running low all the time.
My computer and printer would not recognize the cartridge.
I've ordered remanufactured Canon ink cartridges many times before through Amazon and feel that some of the cartridges actually last longer than the original Canon ones do.

Since you don't get to see what's inside the cartridge, there is no way you can tell if the cartridge is full, so after I replaced the cartridge on my printer, the messages keep saying low, then it ran out in less than 300 pages, I replace another one (I ordered two),
This product was as described,but after installing,my printer still said low ink levels.
Only a few days after instaling this cartridge my printer was say it was low on ink.
The cartridge works great after in my case, hold down the reset/stop button on my canon printer and for $8.00 thats not that much trouble.
sorry, this remanufactured canon ink has arrived and already (one week/10pages) seems to be weak.
This ink works ok in my Canon Pixma MP250 printer.
Works very well,  deeply appreciated the instructions for overcoming the empty cartridge reading, which I did have to use to reset the printer.
Sure, the printer recognizes that they're not Canon brand, and makes you acknowledge it, but they work very well, just as good as the more expensive Canon brand.

The product is just excellent, even as a refurbished part it inmediatelly worked on the printer, the printing is just excellent and they give you the possibility to send them back the old cartridge if you do not have a safe way of disposing it.
my printer didnt recognize this item there fore keeps saying my ink is out, on the plus side , still letting me print with it
This cartridge did not work after installing in my printer.
This cartridge did not work with my printer, it says it is empty.

So with putting in the second cartridge, I printed around 100 sheets at best and within four days of the first cartridge that ran out, the second one did too!Perhaps these were just a "fluke" for me, but it's helped me to realize that I will not be ordering these remanufactured cartridges ever again.
Printer shows E for empty and will not proceed with printing.
The only downside is it does not reset your ink levels so there is always a message saying ink is low.
Even though I know it has ink, my printer keeps telling me it is out and will not print.
I ordered 2 cartridges of 210 and neither had any ink it.
At this time I have not used the ink cartridge in my printer yet, if there are any problems I will post a follow up.
This cartridge worked fine but the ink didn't last as long as a normal one from Canon.
Don'r have chip for printer to recognize, but I don't want to pay Cannon many times more for that single extra.
The product did not work with my Canon PIXMA MP240 although it is one of the listed printers.

passages.text: I removed the smoker before firing up the grill, because the instructions suggested not exposing the smoker to over 275 degrees, I think, and avoiding exposure to direct flame.

At 8:00 PM I preheated my grill to 300 degrees, placed hickory pellets in the pellet smoker, followed directions for lighting, placed smoker and brisket (cold) on the grill, maintained heat at approximately 225 degrees.

However, with the extra airflow my smoker was having a hard time keeping the temperature high enough (I cook baby backs at 225 degrees, the best my smoker could manage running full blast at the highest setting was around 205 degrees).
Company recommended max temp for hot smoking is 275* which is fine for low and slow or cold smokes, but I like to cook my chicken higher.
That way, I could smoke at lower temperatures for a long time, and then raise the temperature to finish the meat or fish.
I followed the directions as outlined in the shippment and smoked three slabs of spare ribs and a chicken, the smokey flavor of the Pit-master pellets won rave reviews from my guest.
I do believe that you could use it to use virtually any grill, smoker, barbecue or similar outside cooker as a cold smoker.
Getting ready to wrap in foil, return to grill and slow cook at 250 degrees until internal temp of 203 degrees.
Awesome cold smoker,and up to 225F is flawless.

The instructions say to keep it under 180 degrees for longest burn times, and that this tray really is for cold smoking, but it worked really well at 225 degrees for me, and I don't have to keep adding chips ever 15 to 20 minutes, which is a real plus.
The best smoker you can get for your grill or smoker,workes great you will never lack smoke with this.
try cold smoking bone-in rib-eyes for about an hour or an hour and a half .Bag them up in zip lock bags and return to the fridge overnight.
I bought this for my Traeger Texas smoker, but keep in mind that if you plan on hot smoking, you need to keep it below 225 in my opinion or it will snuff out.
It was plenty of smoke for the ribs, but for a brisket you want to reload the tray I think.
If you like to smoke meat or even just cold smoke it works great....
I make pork but ribs bacon fish beef you name it and it works for cold and hot smoke!
I filled the tray full of hickory pellets and lite BOTH ends as I like a lot of smoke on my ribs, but it did burn out completely , after a little more than two hours.

This smoker is so simple, inexpensive, and effective that it might be a bit disruptive to the industry if and when it really "catches on." I hope that does, because it's a fun and accessible way for people to improve the taste of their food, even for those without a grill.

passages.text: With this unit, one can quickly, easily (although erratic in nature) test basic pool/spa water chemistry in the form of Bromine, Free Chlorine, Alkalinity and pH.  Understand when using this tester, the results are not going be spot on but they are a decent indicator if you're not wanting to use less convenient testing methods that are consistently more accurate.
For example, today I ran two tests on my pool water...one test gave me a CL reading of 2.6 and the second test (performed exactly the same way, 5 minutes apart) gave me a reading of .6!
I'm glad I verified the readings before I poured hundreds of dollars worth of chemicals in the pool trying to chase the Aquacheck readings.....I'm going back to the drops tests.
The digital readings make balancing your pool chemicals very easy.
The little booklet that comes with it provides lots of valuable and interesting information on how to proceed with your pool chemicals based upon the reading from the device - which is helpful.
test strips provide digital readings on the three most common numbers you need for chlorine pools (Chlorine, pH, Alkalinity).
For pH and chlorine readings, I find the Aquacheck convenient, accurate and time saving; pH and chlorine are the most critical readings in maintaining swimming pool water clarity.
Below are the readings from my "Pool Chemistry" spreadsheet.
Makes adding just the right amount of pool chemicals super easy!
The Chlorine level can range from 0 to 9.8 when the same pool is tested within a 10-minute time frame.

I'm a new pool owner and want to keep on top of getting the pool chemistry settled and stable and be able to keep a bit ahead of the PH impact of the downpours we get here and the chlorine destroying (but VERY pleasant!)

I put chlorine in the spa the night before getting the meter and tested the water the next day and it was showing it low with a reading of 1.  I knew that couldn't be right since I have only a 250 gallon spa and just put chlorine in it 20 hours earlier.
Each time I used this digital reader to test my pool's water the unit gave wildly different readings.

In summary, after a few months of use, when compared to simple test strips or inexpensive pool/spa water test kits, I find this to be a well priced, although a somewhat undependable yet easy to use, digital test strip reader that one can use to monitor and maintain basic pool or spa water chemistry.
I took water samples to my pool supply house to determine which test type was accurate.
Now the Free Chlorine readings varied from somewhat higher than the pool store's to the occasional wildly inaccurate result.
Tested water and took it to a local pool shop.
The first unit I tried came back pretty consistently with VERY high Free Chlorine readings and unacceptably high PH readings relative to my pool supply store's results.

But this unit was reporting PH levels were now at least as much BELOW the pool store's readings as the first one was OVER (just using the numeric values, ignoring the logarithmic nature of the scale).To try to rule out my pool store as being at fault, I took my water sample to another store (that uses a different water anlysis technology) to evaluate the sample and the two store's readings were close enough to give me further confidence that the pool store readings are likely OK.Fortunately Amazon is also great about refunding for a defective item.
In doing this, I'm getting dependable water chemistry readings I feel comfortable setting the spa water chemistry by.
I could dip a test strip in my pool and put it in the AquaChek and get readings, then wipe it off and try again and get seriously different readings, which means it's useless.
